title: Vittoria finally releases tan-wall tubeless Corsa tyres
content:
Cyclist
Vittoria finally releases tan-wall tubeless Corsa tyres

Vittoria today launches its newest additions to its high-end Corsa range of road tyres, the Corsa Pro and the Corsa Pro Control.

The Corsa Pro is the Italian brand’s top racing performance tyre while the Corsa Pro Control is its top rough road racing performance tyre.

The Corsa Pro tyres were first spotted on Jumbo-Visma’s 2023 bikes in December 2022, and according to Vittoria, the tyre has already won 22 stages and 12 one-day WorldTour-level races since the start of the season.

The Corsa Pro comes tubular and tubeless-ready while the Corsa Pro control comes tubeless-ready. This is the first time Vittoria has offered tubeless road tyres with tan-walls.

The Corsa Pro TLR will be available in sizes from 24mm up to 32mm, while the Corsa Pro Control will be offered in widths from 26mm to 34mm. Both tyres will retail for £89.99 / €94.95.

Cotton construction

So, what’s the big deal? Vittoria says the tyres are made using a new construction technology, with a cotton casing and new compound tread which is now completely seamless because the vulcanisation process is done electrically.

Vittoria says the 320 TPI cotton casing increases the tyres suppleness and makes it more adaptable to terrain. This is because compared to nylon, cotton is lighter, more flexible and more supple, which the brand claims results in better ground contact, grip and traction.

‘The cotton casing is the normal from the Corsa family and usually this casing required the tread to be glued on top,’ explains Vittoria product manager, Tomasso Cappella.

‘However now we have developed a new way of doing this, with electrical vulcanization, so there is no gap between the tread and casing, so no glue. The tread and casing are combined together and it creates a fully seamless product.’

The tyres use Vittoria’s latest Silica and graphene compound, and they also have a high-density layer protection belt before the tread surface and a Zylon bead for easy fitting and air retention.

Corsa tread

The Corsa Pro has spaced grooves for a wide contact surface which Vittoria says is a tried and tested tread pattern used by many cyclists and teams in the WorldTour.

The Corsa Pro Control has a new tread design and the tread itself is thicker than the normal Corsa Pro, which the brand says is what makes the tyre ideal for rough terrain, such as cobblestones, and allows it to offer better puncture resistance.

This new tread design, which Vittoria calls a fishbone texture, is said to increase handling capability when cornering and the thicker rubber improves puncture resistance and durability. This extra longevity comes at an expense of around 25g in weight: a 28mm Corsa Pro Control weighs a claimed 320g versus a Corsa Pro at 295g in the same size.

Corsa Pro numbers

According to Vittoria, compared to previous generations the Corsa Pro TLR is 18% more puncture resistant and 12% faster, while the tubular version is 14% faster and offers 7% more puncture resistance.

The Corsa Pro Control is apparently 2% faster and 19% more puncture-resistant than its predecessor.

‘It’s like comparing a Fiat Panda and a Porsche 911 when driving at 100kmh,’ explains Cappella.

‘In one you will feel the speed more, but you will be less in control. In the other you won’t feel like you are going really fast but you are much more in control.’

The Corsa Pro comes in sizes 700×24c up to 700×32c, and sizes 28, 30 and 32 are hookless-compatible.

The Corsa Pro comes in sizes 700×26c up to 700×34c, and sizes 28, 30, 32 and 34 are hookless-compatible. The tyres have a maximum pressure of 72psi.

Vittoria says that its foam tyre insert, the Air Liner road, can be used in the new Corsa Pros and will help to further protect against punctures.

First ride review: Vittoria Corsa Pro

Cyclist got the opportunity to visit Vittoria HQ in Italy to get a feel for the tyres and to ride around the brand’s purpose built cycling park, Vittoria Park.

The park offers 4km of cycling tracks for road, gravel and mountain bikes, and includes surfaces similar to Strade Bianche and Paris Roubaix, so it was the perfect place to try out the new Corsa Pro tyres.

Although I only had a short time to use the new tyres, the experience I did get was positive. Ride quality felt excellent, with the 28mm width providing plenty of volume for comfort and excellent grip. I also found myself agreeing with the ‘Panda vs Porsche’ analogy: despite not feeling like I was going fast, my bike computer said otherwise, and I felt in control.

Obviously I can’t quantify many of Vittoria’s empirical claims, and I can’t attest to long term durability as I haven’t ridden them enough, but my first impression was a good one.

More to the Corsa range

The Corsa road range includes the Corsa N.EXT, the brands lifestyle option, which was introduced last year. Vittoria bills it as a training tyre, with nylon casing which allows for more durability compared to cotton for racing. We gave it a 4.5 out 5-star review when we tested it in July 2022.

Vittoria is also launching the Corsa Pro Speed in 2024 which will be a time trial tyre and which will the complete the brand’s road riding range.

The Corsa tyres come in reusable packaging made from paper pulp which Vittoria says can be used to plant flowers and is fully biodegradable.

The Corsa Pro costs £89.99 / €94.95 for tubeless and £119.99 / €119.00 for tubular.

The Corsa Pro Control costs £89.99 / €94.95.

Both tyres are only available in its natural cotton colour (para/tan sidewall).

The post Vittoria finally releases tan-wall tubeless Corsa tyres appeared first on Cyclist.
author: Emma Cole | Features Writer
